messages.text: Great to hear... Yeah the wine dataset is fun... Good luck with the next one.

<@U1Z90HJG3> The Pandas lecture went well. I could tell their brains were full by the end at 8:25 PM. So from 8:25 to 8:30 I did a demo with Seaborn using `sns.pairplot(data=df)` and `sns.pairplot(data=df[['quality', 'citric acid', 'residual sugar']])`. They had fun with that, as we looked at the data so quickly, and we found that high quality wine in the dataset has low residual sugar. I will get my lecture materials to you for review by Monday for the day 11 lecture.
A practice run sounds like a great idea! I'll do that. Thanks again for your help.
Good luck... Pandas generally benefits from a dry run of some sort

<@U1Z90HJG3> Yeah I can teach from the Jupyter notebook! For sure. In fact I generally teach as code alongs, and keep my slides light. I will go ahead and use the slides as my guide, perhaps on a second screen the students won't see. (got a little old chrome book for that task!) I'll show slides as needed at critical junctures. The slides will keep me on track. Thanks for your feedback! I'm excited to teach the lesson on Thursday
Would you teach from the jupyter notebook
They look good... talking about the important things (iloc vs loc, groupby, reading csv and more), but it is also a lot of slides.

<@U37T36Q77|alicia.key> uploaded a file: <https://gstudents.slack.com/files/alicia.key/F57U8P13Q/ak-pandas-draft1.pdf|ak-Pandas-draft1.pdf> and commented: <@U1Z90HJG3> Here is a copy of what I have so far on my slides for Pandas. What I still need to do is the visualization section, as well as grouping on multiple columns. Where it says demo I can drop down to Jupyter to show a bit of hands on demo (I have a Jupyter notebook I have been building alongside this), but for the most part I have aimed to make the slides self contained. If you have thoughts please let me know! Pandas is coming up on Thursday May 4th in Boulder.

initial_comment.comment: <@U1Z90HJG3> Here is a copy of what I have so far on my slides for Pandas. What I still need to do is the visualization section, as well as grouping on multiple columns. Where it says demo I can drop down to Jupyter to show a bit of hands on demo (I have a Jupyter notebook I have been building alongside this), but for the most part I have aimed to make the slides self contained. If you have thoughts please let me know! Pandas is coming up on Thursday May 4th in Boulder.

messages.text: The g44 WDI students are finishing up their "unfamiliar environments" week. I taught them some Python. Some of them are quite interested in data vis things, so I showed some things with Pandas, Jupyter, and Seaborn to quickly visualize some housing price data I found on Kaggle. There were several students who like the data data vis things.
Google slides are pretty common, but I personally use beamer a bunch

<@U1Z90HJG3> Is there a place where we can share our Intro to Python slides (like a GitHub repo)? I will have a few presentations I am going to make in the next few days I would like to send to you for critique so I can use them. Is using Beamer a common approach or is some other software used? (If not Beamer, apparently, Deckset seems to have some formula support but I haven't tested it yet).
Next lecture on Thursday for me _(so awesome :stuck_out_tongue: )_
I am going to join tonight
Great so far
<@U34BY2K3K> <@U33BKEP9Q> How is the intro to python class in Platte going?
Thanks!

attachments.title: Ubuntu Desktop certified hardware | Ubuntu
attachments.text: Hardware that have been certified for use with Ubuntu.

messages.text:
I would say minimum 8 GB Ram is the only suggested requirement.  If it is not OSX then said student should be sure that Ubuntu plays nicely on that machine.  (Dell, Lenovo, HP) are generally the best.  But here is a website for reference:

<https://certification.ubuntu.com/desktop/>
osx is the easiest.  we also have student using linux.
I have an intro to python student who has spent more time messing with her old Windows machine than learning Python, and she is looking to upgrade. So I figured giving her DSI specs is a safe bet.
Hey everyone! What are the recommended computer specifications for the DSI program?
Thanks <@U1Z90HJG3>. I learned a lot! Both for Python teaching and side projects. See you on Wednesday.
I took off early to go work somewhere quiet.  Hopefully you leaned a bunch!  See you Wednesday.
I will head out soon, but in case I don't see you: I will be back on Wednesday and Thursday as well.
sorry wrong channel..
We usually start lecture at 9:30 but we will be here by 9
We are happy to have you
Looking forward to it!
I am looking forward to seeing you all and Frank on Monday and Thursday next week!
excellent
Thank you, this will be a huge help
<@U37T36Q77|alicia.key> uploaded a file: <https://gstudents.slack.com/files/alicia.key/F4Y703S4Q/unix_and_cli.pdf|Unix and CLI.pdf>
<@U37T36Q77|alicia.key> uploaded a file: <https://gstudents.slack.com/files/alicia.key/F4Y7TPJPK/intro_to_git.pdf|Intro to Git.pdf>
Thanks, you're the best!
I will send it, just a minute
Yes!
<@U37T36Q77> do you have a slide deck for day 1 of the Python Fundamentals course?
Nice to meet you as well, Alicia!
Thanks, and good to meet you Steve and Brent!
Thanks Adam! And Hi Alicia!

Hi Alicia.  Meet Steve and Brent our DSR's here in Denver.  They will be teaching the Python Fundamentals class starting next  week.  I just wanted to open the channel of communication so that you all may share slides, war stories and whatever else.

latest.text: Great to hear... Yeah the wine dataset is fun... Good luck with the next one.
